post.subject: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
Please reply to this post.  Do NOT start a new post for discussions.

Please post all your questions as a reply to this question.  After you make a post, you will be able to see the post of other people - you may reply to their posts also.

This generally breaks down when you start a new post - you cannot then see the post of others and hence participate in the discussion.

post.subject: How to generate white noise (Slide 9)
post.message:
sir,

can you elaborate nature of ξ(n) white noise. how it is generated in reallity. there will be other types of loise as well, abd how they are modeled.

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Sunday, 27 January 2013, 11:52 AM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:26 AM)

post.subject: H(z) will not be deterministic (Slide 9)
post.message:
sir,

since input and output of H(z) are random, in my veiw H(z) will not be deterministic process. please coment.

whether H(z) is LTI? please elaborate properties of H(z) if any.

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Sunday, 27 January 2013, 12:06 PM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:26 AM)

post.subject: Use of ACF and CCF (Slide 12)
post.message:
what is the use of ACF and CCF functions and why z transform of ɛ(n) does not exist?

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Sunday, 27 January 2013, 12:24 PM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:27 AM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
It is difficult to visualise a white noise in reality.  The reason is that two successive samples are uncorrelated.  It is difficult to visualise it.  But the concept of white noise is extremely useful.  All other noise processes can be obtained by filtering white noise.


White noise is approximated by a pseudo random binary sequence.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
The output is not random.  It is related to the input.  By an analysis of an input and the corresponding output, the relation between them is brought out in the form of a transfer function.

Yes, H(z) is the transfer function of an LTI system.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: Using ACF and CCF, we carry out identification, as explained in Chapter 6 of the book.

post.subject: Calculation of inverse of Phi (Slide 32)
post.message:
sir,

for normal equation ΦTWΦθ = ΦTWZ..............

if i simplify it, i get

θ =Φ-1Z,

but in the lecture it wasn't simplified, whether there is any purpose or we cannot do the simplification.

please comment........

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Sunday, 27 January 2013, 4:40 PM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:28 AM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
sir,

i am asking about the inputs and output of H(z) which is placed in the path of noise ξ(n). if have learnt correcly from the lecture, ξ(n) as well as v(n) are random. hence H(z) should not be diterministic process (or whatever we call).

It seems to me that H(z) should not be LTI as well as input and output to it are random and not fixed over time.

please explain! I didn't get your answer.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
Let me try to answer in a different way.  Suppose you subject a transfer function H(z) to a random signal $$\xi$$ and call the output $$v$$.  Suppose that we consider the output $$v$$ also to be a random signal.  Should we, as a result, call H(z) as something different from a transfer function? 

In other words, we assume that the disturbance is also defined by a transfer function and try to fit it with experimental data.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: You are assuming that $$\Phi$$ is square and invertible.  Those assumptions are not present in our approach.  As a matter of fact, $$\Phi$$ will be a tall matrix.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
sir,

thanx, it was good,

but still I can't convince myself about whether H(z) will be LTI. are we assuming it LTI as a simplistic approach?

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
thank you sir,

i didn't made mistake.

post.subject: Correctness of mathematical notation (Slide 14)
post.message:

are the concept of mixed notations mathmatically correct?

please explain.

post.subject: Assigning weights (Slide 25)
post.message:
For least square estimation, how do we determine W(n)=diag(w(n),w(n-1),...,w(n-N))?

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Sunday, 27 January 2013, 8:16 PM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:29 AM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: I am not sure what you mean by "I didn't made mistake" - How can you find the inverse of a nonsquare system?  What do you mean by writing $$\Phi^{-1}$$ when $$\Phi$$ is not a square matrix?

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: It is only a notation.  So long as you assign a mathematically consistent meaning to a notation and be consistent about it, it is perfectly fine.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: There is no theory that explains how to assign weighting factors for different components.  One usually follows a trial and error method: assign some weight to every component of the vector and proceed with solving the system.  In the final result, if you find some component to be larger than allowed, then increase its weight and repeat.  This topic will be discussed again when we deal with Generalised Predictive Control and State Space Control.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: Yes, you may think of it as an approximation.

post.subject: Physical meaning of ACF (Slide 12)
post.message:
Covariance or Variance by definition is measure of spread of data around the mean. Auto covariance function(ACF) is defined for different values of l(lag) and u(k-l) is used in calculation. I didnt get the physical meaning of this definition.

Also video quality for Aliasing part was not good, so please repeat this topic in Class.

post.subject: How to separate noise from signal (Slide 9)
post.message:
The noise is embedded inside the signal instead of coming externally. So, we have to analyse the variation of noise in a signal which is varying itself.


How to we deal with this? In other words, how do we determine if the noise in a signal is white or not?

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 1:59 AM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:42 AM)

post.message:

In the regression eqn, z(k) = phi(k)theta + E(k), we assumed E(k) as negligible. If thats the case then why are we trying to find H(z) in the first place?

post.message:

post.subject: Sampling rate and ZOH (Slide 7)
post.message:
Sir,

In the lecture you have said that Shannon's reconstruction cannot be implemented. In that case faster sampling is used.

But what if necessary instruments for faster sampling is not available. Is ZOH a viable option then ? Can other reconstruction methods be used depending on the type of signal ?

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 3:04 AM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:46 AM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: What we are using is the discrete time approximation.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
It is a two step process.  First find G and attribute the difference to v(n).  Then describe v(n) as a filtered white noise.  Through this, obtain H.  Finally, with G and H as the initial values, do a fitting once again.  This is explained in the book, chapter 6.


This process makes the identification easier.  It is almost like our approach to solve nonlinear equations: first come up with an initial guess; using this as the starting point, arrive at the final solution.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message:
Yes, v(n) is not white noise.  It is the difference between the actual measurement and G(z)u(n).

In simple terms, ergodicity allows us to get an idea of all realisations through what actually happens in time, sequentially.  The second one actually happens and we can measure them.  On the other hand, all the realisations actually don't happen and we can only hypothesize about them.

post.subject: Design of persistent input
post.message:
How to derive a 'persistently exciting' input?

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 9:16 AM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: ARMA models will have the least number of parameters.  This is useful for fast computations.  On the other hand, having least number of parameters may not be the most correct.  For example, MA models give less unbiased estimates, compared to ARMA models - explained in chapter 6.  As a result, people prefer to work with MA models, even if it contains a large number of (say, 500) terms.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: Auto covariance function has only one signal as the input: covariance is taken with the signal itself.  Any two terms of the white noise, if even separated by one time instant, are uncorrelated and hence result in zero, when we carry out the calculations.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: ACF helps find out how a time is correlated with a time shifted version of itself.

post.subject: Re: Lower than sampling rate
post.message: If you reconstruct using values obtained with lower than minimum sampling rate, you will not get the original signal back.

post.subject: Re: white noise nature
post.message: As far as the plant output is concerned, the noise is denoted as v(n), which need not be white.  Based on what it is, we determine H(z).  Please note that H(z) is strictly not a part of the plant.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: Please see my answers to the following two posts: two step process G, H and white noise nature.

post.subject: Re: Can we take v as zero?
post.message: If it is indeed negligible, no need to worry about it.  If it is not negligible, you will have to model it.

post.subject: Re: How do we know white noise
post.message: Calculate the ACF, for example.

post.subject: Re: Sampling rate and ZOH
post.message: If you want to use ZOH, you will have to use many (say, 5 to 10) times the minimum sampling rate!  If you sample at lower than minimum rate NO reconstruction method will work, ZOH, the least of all.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: In Process Control course, we considered transfer functions by taking Laplace transforms but here we are considering z-transforms. Why did not we use z-transform there?

post.subject: Random noise (Slide 13)
post.message:

If it is not, there is any possibility of output v(n) is random for noise input which is not random. Explain any example of the noise which are not random.

post.message:

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 3:31 PM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: Z-transform is defined for discrete functions, and laplace is for continuous functions.

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions (Slide 32)
post.message:
Sir you say that the 'input should be chosen properly' to ensure that the persistence condition is satisfied for determination of the theta vector. Is this done purely by trial and error, or are there techniques that help us know a-priori estimates that ensure the satisfaction of the condition?

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 4:01 PM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions (Slide 32)
post.message:
Sir, we have assumed that ΦTWΦ is non-singular. What if it is singular? Is there a possibility of such a thing happeneing? 

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 4:08 PM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: We choose our input signals such that the matrix turns out to be singular. However I don't know if there is a definite way to ensure such a choice of input signal without knowing the system except for trial and error, which is my doubt as asked above.

post.subject: Why regression in AR? (Slide 16)
post.message:
Sir,

For the ARMA model, what is the motivation in defining regression of the previous outputs and averaging of the previous inputs for prediction of a random series?

I understand it is just a model, but why regression?

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 4:52 PM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 6:38 PM)

post.subject: Random walk model (Slide 15)
post.message:
Can we use Random Walk (RW) model  instead of MA ?

Are there any conditions for the selection of model ?

(Edited by Kannan Moudgalya - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 4:55 PM)

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 6:39 PM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions
post.message: Why are we taking the fourior of sample and then inverse fourior to get continuous signal instead of taking higher order interpolation? Will both method produce similiar results?

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions (Slide 7)
post.message:
If we have a guess of frequencies in desired output and input. Then applying higher order frequency-band filter over output will cutoff the noise in the region. The we will have the rough guess of frequency of nosie so we can find it using fourior series. Can it be possible to use this method?

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 5:11 PM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions (Slide 13)
post.message:
What is the reason behind coming up with the concept called white noise? Do the noises in real systems have characteristics similar to white noise?

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 5:26 PM)

post.subject: Re: Identification: please post your questions (Slide 15)
post.message:
Can we model transient noise? 

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Monday, 28 January 2013, 5:31 PM)

post.subject: Re: Why regression in AR?
post.message: Otherwise, you will have a large number of MA terms - obvious if you do long division.

post.subject: Re: Random noise
post.message: Only $$\xi$$ is white noise - this means that even successive values are uncorrelated.

post.subject: Re: Assigning weights
post.message: Yes.
